awd_titl_txt: The Role Of Environmental Structures In The Emergence Of Cultural Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
The research team of Dr. William Ringle (Davidson College), Dr. Tomás Gallareta Negrón (INAH/ Mexico), and Dr. George J. Bey (Millsaps College) will examine relationships between cultivation, topography, settlement, and regionalism among the ancient Maya inhabitants of the Puuc region of Yucatan, Mexico. Although agriculture usually dominated the economies of archaic civilizations, the manner in which production was organized is often unclear, especially cases in which investment in agricultural facilities appears minimal. Nor is it clear, in many pre-monetary societies, how agricultural produce was converted into "bankable" wealth and political capital. A related question is the role of elites in such activities. Were they primarily courtiers or warriors, dependent upon the largesse of a ruler, were they absentee landlords resident in towns, or did they more actively direct agricultural production (and perhaps that of other commodities)? At a broader level, do agricultural regimes contribute to inter-community forms of social integration via cooperation in landscape management, perhaps leading to the genesis of regional forms of identity? The Puuc region is interesting in being both well-defined topographically and a distinct regional Maya subculture, famous for its elegant architectural style. Soils are generally fertile, but cultivable tracts were limited by numerous karst hills often supporting residences. Virtually no surface water was available and instead had to be collected in cisterns or reservoirs. Nearly abandoned after about AD 1000, the Puuc had until then had hosted one of the highest site densities in the tropical lowlands. It was also prosperous, with many residing in masonry houses faced with superb stonework. Such houses may have been one way of "banking" tribute revenues and creating political capital Thus this research will be of value in demonstrating how such a landscape was successfully managed for centuries as well as providing insight into its eventual collapse. The project will also foster the project's long history of training both Mexican and US undergraduate and graduate students, a substantial number of whom have come from traditionally under-represented populations.

Because these questions play out across distances too great to be covered by pedestrian survey, this study will commission LiDAR imagery of a 138 km2 study sample. The sample will target two major physiographic zones of the Puuc, the Bolonchen hills and the Yaxhom Valley, to assess how differences of terrain affected urban settlement and organization. To date no Puuc site of significant size has been fully mapped; this sample will provide complete coverage of at least six, as well as several small centers and the hinterlands connecting them. LiDAR will aid in identifying water storage features and masonry structures. It will also allow assessment of the construction industry by determining the distribution of lime kilns. Visual classification will be followed up by ground verification of approximately 15% of the sample, as well as test excavations to assess chronology. Results will permit development of rational plans for management of the archaeological remains within the study zone and will provide data useful to agencies interested in Puuc forest conservation.

por.por_cntn:
The fundamental premise of settlement archaeology is that understanding any past society requires an assessment of its demography and how its population was disposed with respect to natural and cultural features. Earlier work established the Puuc region of Yucatan, the subject of this project, as an important regional culture of the ancient Maya, but dense vegetation and rugged terrain prevented full mapping of any site. Information on community structure, rural populations, and intersite interactions was thus wanting. Aerial lidar imaging removed these impediments, permitting complete and rapid coverage of a study zone of 478 km2 at a resolution of .5 m. We identified 65 sites over 2 ha, many unreported, as well as nearly 14,000 platforms and over 2,100 annular structures. We estimate regional population density at approximately 300 people/km2, with a total of 75-113,000 people, much higher than at present.

We also wished to investigate settlement differences between two major topographic zones, the Yaxhom Valley to the north and the hills to the south. In both, farmers favored “flats” filled with alluvium, but those in the Valle are much larger. They very clearly avoided building their houses in flats, suggesting careful land management, but did not invest greatly in terracing. We did identify the first agricultural terraces in the Puuc, but only on eight of the many hundreds of hills. Thus, any agricultural success was due to organizational improvements. Unsurprisingly, the largest sites surrounded the Yaxhom Valley flats, but some large flats in the hills were lightly populated, suggesting that the regional carrying capacity was never attained.

Lacking rivers and lakes, Puuc water procurement was another question. Cisterns incorporated into house platforms were one solution. Although less than a meter wide, the mouths of these can usually be seen in lidar data. Reservoirs were another option, the largest of which could have provided for thousands for several months. Excavations at the largest indicate it originated sometime in the Middle Preclassic period. The others we examined either dated to the Late Classic (AD 600-900) or had virtually no artifacts. We identified 34 aguadas in the lidar, demonstrating that only a minority of sites were within walking distance.

Lidar revealed that stone working was a major industry of the region, not surprising given the many masonry structures. Lime was produced in annular structures for use in mortar, to soften maize, and possibly to purify drinking water. Previously known from a few dozen examples, over 2100 were identified in both rural and urban contexts. We were also able to identify several quarries, some of which involved the removal of large sections of hillsides.

Fieldwork involved ground survey and limited excavations across the range of sites. Nearly all had masonry structures. In the smallest, what appear to have been barrios were clustered around a single masonry structure, probably the house of its headman. Compression of settlement in larger site made barrios difficult to discern, but occasionally a complex of vaulted structures surrounded by commoner houses occupied a hill, forming production segments for cultivation, stone working, or other tasks. At larger sites, masonry structures comprise up to a third of all buildings. We argue they were given as a token of royal favor, tightly controlled as to size and further expansion.

Another objective was to assess the antiquity of Puuc settlement, since some argue it was only a Late-Terminal Classic phenomenon. Instead, we found a strong Middle Preclassic occupation throughout, including deposits of the oldest known pottery in northwest Yucatan. We also identified multiple examples of two types of early civic groups: a smaller plazuela group with an adjacent ballcourt and enormous acropolises, some with ballcourts, among the largest structures ever built in the Puuc. Puuc communities therefore thrived nearly as early as any in the lowlands.

The Puuc may have declined for a time, but about AD 600-750 numerous small communities were founded (72 in all), each built around standardized groups of civic architecture. After this period of uniformity, communities began to range greatly in size, as did civic architecture. Nevertheless, floor plans and associated sculpture suggests certain building forms were widely shared and served similar functions.

We have conflicting evidence regarding the notorious Maya “collapse”. Sufficient land seems to have been available, and we found no evidence of fortifications. However, some buildings were abandoned rapidly and construction stopped on others. Conversely, several instances of a late post-monumental architectural group have been identified throughout our sample. Thus, at this point we have evidence for both immediate and less precipitous abandonment.

Digital methods such as GIS, photogrammetry, and AI have been key to our work. Several academic papers and presentations have appeared, we have been featured in two television documentaries, and an edited volume is now underway. Lidar is also proving an invaluable resource for cultural management of this precious heritage.
